module_quizzes.description: Quick check to make sure you're ready to continue

questions.question: What was Sarah's profession before she became a Functional Medicine practitioner?
questions.explanation: Sarah was an ICU nurse for 12 years before burnout led her to discover Functional Medicine.

questions.question: According to Sarah, people discover Functional Medicine by accident.
questions.explanation: Sarah says 'People don't discover Functional Medicine by accident. They find it when they're ready for healing.'

questions.question: How many modules are in this Mini Diploma?
questions.explanation: The Mini Diploma has 3 main modules plus the Welcome module and Final Exam.

module_quizzes.description: Test your understanding of the 7 Body Systems Model

questions.question: According to the 7 Body Systems Model, what percentage of your immune system is located in your gut?
questions.explanation: 70-80% of your immune system is located in your gut, which is why gut health is foundational.

questions.question: What percentage of your serotonin (the 'happy' chemical) is made in the gut?
questions.explanation: 90% of serotonin is produced in the gut, which explains the gut-mood connection.

questions.question: According to the Root-Cause Pyramid, which system should you address LAST?
questions.explanation: Hormones should be addressed AFTER foundations, gut, stress, and detox are balanced.

questions.question: Traditional medicine treats SYSTEMS, while Functional Medicine treats SYMPTOMS.
questions.explanation: It's the opposite: Traditional medicine treats symptoms, Functional Medicine treats systems.

questions.question: What is the correct healing order according to the Root-Cause Pyramid?
options: A) Hormones ‚Üí Gut ‚Üí Stress ‚Üí Detox ‚Üí Foundations
B) Foundations ‚Üí Gut ‚Üí Stress ‚Üí Detox ‚Üí Hormones
C) Stress ‚Üí Hormones ‚Üí Gut ‚Üí Foundations ‚Üí Detox
D) Detox ‚Üí Foundations ‚Üí Hormones ‚Üí Gut ‚Üí Stress
questions.explanation: The correct order is: Foundations ‚Üí Gut ‚Üí Stress ‚Üí Detox ‚Üí Hormones (then advanced protocols).

module_quizzes.description: Test your understanding of the case study

questions.question: How old was Michelle when she came for help?
questions.explanation: Michelle was 42 years old, a working mom with two kids and a full-time job.

questions.question: What did Michelle's conventional doctors tell her?
options: C) 'Your labs are normal. You're just getting older.'
D) 'You should see a Functional Medicine practitioner'
questions.explanation: Her doctors dismissed her symptoms, saying her labs were normal and she was 'just getting older.'

questions.question: What gut issues did Functional Medicine find in Michelle?
options: B) Low stomach acid, SIBO, and leaky gut
questions.explanation: Michelle had low stomach acid, SIBO (small intestinal bacterial overgrowth), and leaky gut.

questions.question: What explained Michelle's 3am wake-ups?
questions.explanation: Michelle had cortisol spikes at 3am ‚Äî a classic stress pattern caused by HPA axis dysfunction.

questions.question: How long did Michelle's transformation take?
questions.explanation: Michelle's protocol was 12 weeks: Weeks 1-4 (Foundations + Gut), 5-8 (Stress + Detox), 9-12 (Hormones).

module_quizzes.description: Reflection questions about your path forward

questions.question: What are the two paths forward after completing this Mini Diploma?
options: A) Path 1: Get more tests. Path 2: Take medication.
B) Path 1: Personal transformation. Path 2: Help others heal.
C) Path 1: Wait and see. Path 2: Do nothing.
D) Path 1: Find a doctor. Path 2: Join a gym.
questions.explanation: The two paths are: Personal Transformation (heal yourself) or Help Others Heal (become certified).

questions.question: According to Sarah, you need to be a doctor or have a health background to become a Functional Medicine Health Coach.
questions.explanation: Sarah says 'Your struggle is your qualification. Your experience is your credibility.'

questions.question: You need to be completely 'fixed' and healthy before you can help others.
questions.explanation: Sarah says 'You don't need to be fixed to help others. You just need to be a few steps ahead.'

final_exam.title: Functional Medicine Mini Diploma ‚Äî Final Exam
final_exam.description: Complete this 10-question exam to earn your Mini Diploma certificate

questions.question: What is the MAIN difference between conventional medicine and Functional Medicine?
options: A) Conventional medicine is free, Functional Medicine costs money
B) Conventional medicine treats symptoms, Functional Medicine treats root causes
C) Conventional medicine uses supplements, Functional Medicine uses drugs
questions.explanation: Conventional medicine focuses on symptom management, while Functional Medicine addresses the underlying root causes.

questions.question: How many body systems are in the Functional Medicine framework taught in this course?
questions.explanation: The 7 Body Systems Model includes: Gut, Hormones, Immune/Inflammation, Detox, Energy, Stress, and Structural.

questions.question: According to the course, which body system should ALWAYS be addressed first?
questions.explanation: The gut is foundational because it affects immunity, inflammation, nutrient absorption, and hormone processing.

questions.question: Why do most people fail to heal their hormones?
options: A) They don't take enough supplements
B) They try to fix hormones BEFORE healing gut, stress, and detox
D) They don't drink enough water
questions.explanation: Hormones should be addressed LAST, after foundations, gut, stress, and detox are balanced.

questions.question: In Michelle's case study, what percentage did her anxiety reduce by after 12 weeks?
questions.explanation: Michelle's anxiety reduced by 80% and she was able to get off her anxiety medication.

questions.question: What is 'estrogen dominance'?
options: B) High estrogen relative to progesterone
questions.explanation: Estrogen dominance means high estrogen compared to progesterone, often caused by poor liver detoxification.

questions.question: Chronic inflammation is behind joint pain, fatigue, brain fog, and stubborn weight gain.
questions.explanation: Chronic inflammation affects multiple systems and is a root cause of many chronic symptoms.

questions.question: According to the course, what controls 90% of your serotonin production?
questions.explanation: 90% of serotonin is produced in the gut, which explains the gut-brain connection and mood issues.

questions.question: What does Sarah say about needing a medical background to become a health coach?
options: A) You must have a nursing degree
B) You need at least 5 years of medical experience
C) Your struggle is your qualification; your experience is your credibility
D) You need to be completely healthy first
questions.explanation: Sarah emphasizes that lived experience and personal healing journeys are powerful qualifications.

questions.question: What nutrient deficiencies contributed to Michelle's fatigue, hair loss, and poor recovery?
options: B) Low B12, ferritin, Vitamin D, and magnesium
questions.explanation: Michelle had multiple deficiencies: low B12, ferritin (iron stores), Vitamin D, and magnesium.
